summary.grammarTip:
Ordinalzahlen (Ordinal Numbers)

Ordinal numbers are used to express rank or order (first, second, third...). In German, they are essential for telling the date.

Formation Rules

  • For numbers 1 to 19, add the ending -te.
  • For numbers 20 and higher, add the ending -ste.
  • There are a few special forms to remember.
NumberOrdinal NumberNotes
1der ersteSpecial form
2der zweite
3der dritteSpecial form
4der vierte
7der siebteSpecial form (drops -en)
8der achte
19der neunzehnte
20der zwanzigsteRule change: -ste
21der einundzwanzigste
30der drei√üigste
100der hundertste

Using Ordinal Numbers for Dates

To state a date when an event happens, use the preposition am (an + dem), which puts the ordinal number in the Dative case. This means it will always end in -en.

Pattern: am + Ordinal Number (-en ending) + Month

  • Ich habe Geburtstag am ersten Dezember.
  • Die Schule beginnt am dritten September.
  • Das Fest ist am zwanzigsten Juli.

Adjective vs. Date

Like any adjective, ordinal numbers decline based on the case and article. The am + ...en form is specifically for dates.

  • Nominativ: Der erste Tag war sch√∂n. (The first day was nice.)
  • Dativ: Ich komme am ersten Tag. (I'm coming on the first day.)

Basic Declension: der erste, die erste, das erste, am ersten (Dativ)
